title: Bulgaria’s Georgieva in one-horse race for IMF top job
text:
Kristalina Georgieva is the sole candidate to become the International Monetary Fund’s managing director | Sean Gallup/Getty Images Bulgaria’s Georgieva in one-horse race for IMF top job World Bank boss faces no challengers in her bid to lead International Monetary Fund.

World Bank boss Kristalina Georgieva is the sole candidate to become the International Monetary Fund’s managing director this fall.

The IMF today confirmed the Bulgarian is the only nominee to replace the outgoing incumbent Christine Lagarde, who’s set to become European Central Bank president on November 1.

“The period for submitting nominations for the position of the next Managing Director closed on Friday, September 6,” the IMF statement said. “One nominee, Ms. Kristalina Georgieva, currently Chief Executive Officer of the World Bank and a Bulgarian national, has confirmed willingness to be considered as a candidate.”

Georgieva’s nomination comes after weeks of talks between EU finance ministers, who were determined to keep a European at the helm of the IMF — as has traditionally been the case since the IMF’s formation in 1945.

The 66-year-old came out top of a list of names put together by ministers, which also included former Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem, Eurogroup President Mário Centeno and Bank of England Governor Mark Carney.

Under pressure from France, the IMF waived its 65-year-old age limit for applicants to take up the role.

Georgieva now faces a series of meetings with the IMF’s executive directors about her candidacy. The selection process is set to end by October 4, the IMF said.

The Bulgarian was previously the European commissioner in charge of the EU budget before she left at the end of 2016 to join the World Bank in January 2017.
description: World Bank boss faces no challengers in her bid to lead International Monetary Fund.
